stories.title: A Guide to Asking Robots to Design Stained Glass Windows

stories.text:
I’ve become rigid over the years in my thinking and my creative spark just isn’t what it used to be. Maybe it’s age, maybe other factors. I want to get back my mojo and be more ‘neuroplastic’ as it were.

How do I achieve this?

What hacks can I use to be more creative & inspired and break out of rigid approaches to getting creative work done?
stories.title: Ask HN: How to Stop Being Rigid?

stories.text:
I'd like to buy a PineNote in a few months, but development although improving isn't there yet, so I wonder if there are other models worth of consideration from a tinkerer/privacy conscious user point of view. I don't mean hacking the reader or flash it with a FOSS firmware, but would love to see some features most consumer products usually lack along with others I would need.

0- Not tied to any online or cloud service, no online "activation" etc. 1- Enough horsepower to not require too much time for page flips when reading complex pdfs. 2- 10 inches minimum, possibly 13". I mostly read electronics books, and schematics/graphs on smaller screens are a royal nightmare. 3- Support for NFS/CIFS local network shares 4- No need for drawing functions, editing or annotations, reading alone is more than enough 5- Bonus: a decent mp3 player and a 3.5 headphone jack, but those aren't required at all. 6- Same as above for a reading front light: welcome but not required.

I plan to wait at least a couple months, possibly more, in the hope the PineNote development makes it ready for general use, but just in case, any recommendations? Thanks!
stories.title: PineNote aside, what privacy respecting e-paper reader would you recommend?
